text: So just take one behavior change. Stop drinking and using. Or just one specific example of stop using. Stop using cigarettes. I just brought that up as a specific example. But the kinds of algorithms that I'm developing, when I'm done, I plan to have about two dozen of them that will address all of the major things for which the mindfulness practice is useful. Now, one of the things that I do is I use a shotgun strategy. I describe the same thing in half a dozen different ways. That is the goal of what I hold out as the ideal for conceptual communication. It's 100% my responsibility. Confucius said not to teach is the teacher's fault, not to learn is the student's fault. But I disagree with Confucius. I think it's 100% the teacher's responsibility. That's what I hold out as my goal, OK. That's not the same as what I just said. I just described a stupid question. And I described it as stupid for a reason. One of the important trainings in being a good teacher is to also be happy when you get stupid questions and not, OK, so you may have thought I was being very judgmental. So it's taken me years to train myself out of this, you know, this goddammit, how stupid can you be, OK, to totally train that away. The idea is to just get rid of that completely so that you, it's like infinite patience kind of thing. Infinite patience. And that's another one of the things that I forgot to mention is a skill. Sure, but there is also the, to say that something is stupid is to impose an assumption on the situation. And I think that that's really where the issue comes up. Because the assumption is that you conveyed everything that this person needed to know. And the reality is that you didn't. Yes, they didn't. And that's what you just said. Do you have an algorithm for grief and loss, or? It's the same algorithm. All emotions would be dealt with the same way. The basic algorithm for dealing with anything, is that large enough? OK. The basic algorithm for dealing with anything is break it up into its pieces, learn to keep track of the pieces in real time, learn how not to interfere with the pieces, focus on the individual pieces until you experience each individual piece as effortless spirit, and then focus on the aggregate as effortless spirit. That's the basic algorithm for everything within the mindfulness practice. There's many other practices. But the basic, if you want to have one, what is the basic that you do? You break it up into its components. You learn to keep track of the components. You learn to not interfere with the components. And then things deal in. Well, whatever the components may be. In the broad case of anything that involves a sense of self, an emotion is a particular case of self. Anything that involves a sense of self, the components in this case are talk, image, and feel. But there are subcomponents. For example, feel has qualities, locations. Those are subcomponents. But basically, if it deals with self, it's talk, image, and feel. Whether it's the sense of self as controller, self as perceiver, self as sufferer, it's going to be talk, image, and feel. So we can go from the most general algorithm, break it up into its components. You learn to keep track of the components. You learn how to not interfere with them. That's called equanimity. That process reaches a certain critical momentum. And each of the components, when you pay attention to them individually, dissolves back into spirit energy. Then you collectively pay attention to them. And the whole thing dissolves back into spirit energy. And at that point, you have a spiritual solution to the problem. That's the general algorithm. Specifically, if it's emotion, it's going to be talk, image, and feel. Yes? My question, in my work, it seems I have had a lot of people. I do some body work. It's a matter of trying things, seeing what works. I'll try to have them watch the thoughts, the judging thoughts. I find that that's, I mean, they can do that to a certain point. But there's so much identification with the thoughts. So it's just a matter of practicing this problem. Got to do more. And if they think that they're going to be able to deal with the forces that fuck up life and human history with just mindfulness light, well, that's just unrealistic. It takes industrial strength mindfulness. Yes? How do you know when you're ready to be a facilitator? What we look for is that you're very familiar with the techniques as we present them, that you have used them successfully for dealing with real life issues. So you have the confidence. And then, although it's in no way required, it's a nice feature if you have had previous experience in communication with people and that kind of stuff. But that's not an absolute. I mean, many of our facilitators have not had previous experience. But somebody that we know already has communication skills, it's very nice if they've also had. But the main criteria we look for are, have you done enough retreats that you're very familiar with the techniques? Because you're going to have to guide people through techniques. And the other is, do you have the experiential confidence? Because you've used it for real stuff. Because you're going to have to guide people through real stuff. So that's how you know. Through having done the practice of meditation, I've become painfully aware at times of the fact that there's a very active filtering mechanism in the mind, which, in the short term, tends to prevent me from seeing certain very obvious truths. Because I tend to filter the world through my ego concept and my identity of who I am. And if it's inconsistent with that, I tend to reject that information. So extrapolation, I assume that this is true for other people as well. And I know from experience that just staying in the meditation, putting your face up against the wall, and facing those things that appear to be painful works. And there's a process that tends to dissolve the filtering mechanism. So let me just give a quick and dirty. There's a word in Sanskrit, mana. It actually comes from the root ma, which means to measure. And it's cognate to the English word measure, ultimately. Mana is ego measuring, which is to say comparing. I'm better. I'm worse. I have worth. I don't have worth relative to other people. Now, that's a very deep conditioning inside a human being. We get that from competition early on in many, many areas of I have a better house than my friend, or my friend has a better house than me. It starts, and it's deep. And it's in all of us. So measuring obviously means a sense of being better than or a sense of being less than. And any mana is mana. Pride or self-deprecation are both mana. And they're not distinguished in Buddhism. It's just comparing, ego comparison, any kind of ego comparison, any kind of feeling worthy or unworthy kind of thing. So how you work with that is realize that it is a deep conditioning. And upon occasion, deconstruct it, whether it's positive or negative, back into pure spirit. The thing about not being sure, like, I thought I was right on this one. Now it's not so clear. The one thing to be clear about in that case is that there are two things a human being can do in that situation. They're both valid. And they're both worth exploring. At least upon occasion, for a specific duration. Then these are the two freedoms that a human being has. To think, feel, think, feel, think, feel, think, feel, talk, talk, think, feel, talk, think, feel, until you've somehow resolved those two conflicting cells. Or to dissolve the whole structure of need to know. And as you learn to dissolve the structure of need to know, then other modes of knowing begin to arise that sometimes can help you resolve it. It's not a magic bullet. It's just things that you just can't figure out, you know? And you can't, and you just have to accept that. OK?

segments.text: So just take one behavior change.
Stop drinking and using.
Or just one specific example of stop using.
Stop using cigarettes.
How many gigabucks would that save a year
if everybody that wanted to stop using?
So when you're talking about a general algorithm
for behavior change, you're talking about big time stuff
here.
This kind of procedure, there's something similar
that I've developed for any kind of behavior change.
So I just don't get too fixated on pain,
is what I'm saying.
I just brought that up as a specific example.
But the kinds of algorithms that I'm developing,
when I'm done, I plan to have about two dozen of them
that will address all of the major things
for which the mindfulness practice is useful.
I actually published an article in the,
what's that called, Shambhala Sun,
where I actually gave an algorithm for pain dissolution
that a person could read themselves and follow.
That had text, and it says, if this happens, go here.
If this happens, go here kind of thing.
Mary, did you have your hand up?
What about taking this into hospitals or into places
sort of semi, you know, somebody says, so-and-so's dying.
Could you come and do a guided interactive
or just a meditation or meditate with them in the hospital?
Is there a program of your facilitation
that does any professional stuff like that?
No, because they do it in their spare time.
They're busy people.
Now, of course, if it's a special case,
I mean, they're free to use the skills
that they learned from me any way they want.
So if they've got friends, you know,
or friends of friends, they can do that.
But we have no official program.
And in general, I don't work with the general public
because I just couldn't.
I work with people that are already in the meditation community.
Now, what happens is every once in a while,
I get a very strong request,
and I'm able to, for whatever reason,
work with somebody that is not in the meditation community.
In former times, when I had more time,
I did a lot of work with people
that weren't in the meditation community.
And that was good because I learned
that you could induce these things in rank beginners
with no background whatsoever.
And that was important.
But right now, in general, our facilitators and myself
limit ourselves to the community.
But if they want, they can use it,
and they do use it on their friends and whatever.
It's a wonderful thing.
Yeah, Hoshin?
The handout you gave, you talk about, you know,
subtle, conceptual, experiential teaching.
I was wondering if you could take some time
to relate that to another aspect,
which I think is reflected in other traditions of Zen,
perhaps, which has to do more with the non-linear,
the empathetic, the poetic aspects,
which are also aspects of teaching.
Yes.
OK, I know they're also aspects of practice.
You know, you can tell somebody to sit down
and do this series of steps.
You can also tell them to sit down and stop doing any of the
things that you're doing.
Yes, very much so.
So, you know, if you could figure out
that's very close to things I'm interested in.
Yes, that's actually a good balance.
Of course, the empathetic comes under the category
of subtle teaching, because that's
the merging with the person.
Because if you're in a meditative state,
then you're becoming the person that you're
interacting with.
In my experience, yes, it's very interesting.
As you asked the question, of course,
it's making me think about it.
When I get all this other stuff in place
and completely internalized, that's
when the poetry starts to come out for me.
This whole infrastructure is all in place.
It's completely internalized.
I don't have to think about it.
And then I find myself saying, you know,
amazing juxtapositions of words with energy and assonance
and rhyme that are basically prosodic qualities,
poetic qualities, that have just seemed to come out of nowhere.
So I guess for me, the answer is I get this all internalized
to where it doesn't involve any efforting or thinking for me
to lead a person.
And then I just lay back.
And a lot of times, it is quite true
that not something different from this procedure comes out,
but maybe a new procedure or a new subtlety
or a new way of phrasing will just sort of arise out
of nowhere, literally out of nowhere.
So there are people who may come to meditation
and ask, do we talk meditation?
And then they're given this very logical sequence,
and it doesn't relate.
They can't get into it.
It's too much up here.
That's more in the direction of the question that I'm asking,
because it's related to the aspect of teaching.
Some of these people will come, and then they'll go away.
And you talked earlier about communication, reaching out.
And there must be some way of communicating.
What I'm usually interested in is
to give them an experience right off the bat.
Now, after they've had that experience,
they may want to internalize these algorithms,
or they may not.
Maybe they have some other interpretation,
but at least they've got an experience.
And I think that in terms of bringing
a person of experience to an experience,
this is a fairly safe way to go about it.
But whether a person chooses to meditate
by this kind of algorithm, or for that matter,
whether they choose to meditate with any sense of any goal
at all, is, as you quite correctly point out,
a basic watershed in the whole field of mysticism.
There's absolutely these two approaches.
And one will tend to go with the other one.
One will go with the other.
So the two approaches being efforting versus non-efforting.
Or what I perceive as being a balance, where both are actually
useful approaches in different contexts,
just like you have different algorithms
in different contexts, actually.
One of the possibilities is to sit down and do nothing.
No, but it's true.
Well, OK.
So I just present this as a way of understanding
how guidance can be given, and a way
of explaining why it can be so effective.
I guess I would say that.
But for this to work, there's certainly,
that's why I said that the subtle teaching is at the core.
Remember, subtle teaching always involves
some sort of hard space, even though the algorithms are
completely mechanical, literally mechanical.
So the person, unless there's a caring and emerging
as you do this, it's not going to be as effective.
And then the other thing, just to repeat what I said,
is that sometimes I feel that I'm very intuitive when
I work with people.
But I know that this structure is
what underlies that intuition.
This is so thoroughly internalized for me
that I can then let other forces play,
and they turn out to be effective.
I don't think that's necessary, though.
I think you could just pull it out of the ether
without this kind of structure if you were intuitive enough.
Yes?
Two questions.
Do you have a handout that is like general basic questions
people ask?
You mean a fact sheet for meditation?
It's not a joke.
That's what she means.
An FAQ sheet for meditation.
No, I don't.
I do not.
Someday I will.
It's one of my many projects.
But actually, that was something that I
was going to suggest that you guys work on as a homework
assignment.
In doing the conceptual piece, remember
I said that when somebody says this is a dumb question
or this is a simple question, they're
almost always asking a basic question.
Here's a homework assignment that you can
do for your conceptual piece.
Make a list of the most basic questions about meditation,
and then start thinking about how
you'd answer them to different kinds of people.
That would include, what is meditation?
Why do meditation?
By the way, I said how you would answer, not an answer.
How you would answer it, you might give a list of answers.
So what is it?
Why do you do it?
How do you do it?
And why and how do you do it when?
And fill in the blank when.
When you're so emotionally upset that, you know,
et cetera, et cetera, et cetera.
You know, it's amazing.
I'll go through this whole explanation
of how to work with emotions.
This whole explanation, dividing it into like all,
you know, you've heard me.
I've already done it here to a certain extent.
And somebody will pop off with a question like, OK,
that's all well and good, but what good
is the meditation going to do when I'm really angry?
How can I meditate when I'm really angry?
I've just given an hour talk about how
to deconstruct emotions.
And this person is popping off with, yeah, I get all that,
but what do I do when I'm angry?
Now, of course, what you want to do is you want to say, hello.
It's like, were you listening?
But if you do that, then you're not really being very kind.
And teaching is kindness.
So I forgot to mention this in the conceptual piece.
There's another training.
There are stupid questions, too, that aren't basic questions.
They're stupid questions.
What is a stupid question?
It's when they ask you the question that you just
fucking answered.
And they ask you that same question again
without realizing it.
That's a stupid question.
But if you didn't communicate it, is it?
Yeah.
No, in this case, you communicated.
They were too stupid to realize that anger is an emotion.
That's stupid.
They didn't receive it.
You communicated, OK.
But communication is a two-way street, Jim.
And if you're speaking, and you get to vectors,
and I'm a virgin person, and I go, oh, hell,
there he goes on vectors again.
And I turn off while you're still
trying to communicate with me.
I turn off my part of this communication process.
Then you get to the end, and I go, well, you know,
I wonder what I should do about anger.
No, that's not the same.
I just said, I just got done talking about emotions, OK.
And they asked me what to do about anger.
That's not the same at all.
You're saying, in this case, I didn't.
You're correct, OK.
If you don't know what to do about anger
after I've described anger as an abstract phase space,
and you're supposed to take the differential operators
on that vector, OK, if you don't know
how to deal with your anger after you've heard that,
that is my fault, OK.
And it is not at all a stupid question on your part
to say, wait a minute, could you explain that
in a different way, OK.
That's a completely different question.
That's not a dumb question, OK.
It is absolutely my responsibility to communicate.
It is 100% the responsibility of the teacher to communicate.
And if communication is not taking place,
it's always the responsibility of the teacher
to make the communication take place.
That is the goal that the teacher should have, OK.
In my mind, it is never the responsibility of the student.
If there's a breakdown in communication,
it's my responsibility.
And I've got to refine my skills or whatever.
Now, one of the things that I do is I use a shotgun strategy.
I describe the same thing in half a dozen different ways.
So the people that don't get the vector paradigm
will get some other paradigm, hopefully.
If you don't, then you have every right
to ask until I can give you the answer that satisfies you, OK.
That is the goal of what I hold out
as the ideal for conceptual communication.
It's 100% my responsibility.
Confucius said not to teach is the teacher's fault,
not to learn is the student's fault.
But I disagree with Confucius.
I think it's 100% the teacher's responsibility.
That's what I hold out as my goal, OK.
That's not the same as what I just said.
I just described a stupid question.
And I described it as stupid for a reason.
One of the important trainings in being a good teacher
is to also be happy when you get stupid questions and not,
OK, so you may have thought I was being very judgmental.
But I was trying to convey, in fact, the exact opposite.
You do get stupid questions.
And when you get them, to have infinite patience
and just go back to square one.
It's like dirty sex that you were
talking about the other night.
You clear the layers away until you
get the Christian understanding.
That's right.
That's right.
So when you get a stupid question, like I say,
our proclivity is, it's like, hello, where have you been?
It's like, I just explained that, OK.
But to not have that reaction in the slightest,
but just do it absolutely as though they had just
asked the question out of the blue.
You just answer it very matter-of-factly and very
kindly, OK.
So it's taken me years to train myself out of this,
you know, this goddammit, how stupid
can you be, OK, to totally train that away.
The idea is to just get rid of that completely
so that you, it's like infinite patience kind of thing.
Infinite patience.
And that's another one of the things
that I forgot to mention is a skill.
I think the problem has to do with the fact
that the word stupid has a veil of stupid.
Well, I did that to get people's attention.
Sure, but there is also the, to say that something is stupid
is to impose an assumption on the situation.
And I think that that's really where the issue comes up.
Because the assumption is that you conveyed everything
that this person needed to know.
And the reality is that you didn't.
Yes, they didn't.
And that's what you just said.
You have to go through the process.
But if you recognize that, then it's
no longer a stupid question.
Well, it's true.
You conveyed everything that they
need to know except the piece of information
that anger is an emotion.
And you failed to convey that to them.
That's right.
Yes.
Do you have an algorithm for grief and loss, or?
It's the same algorithm.
All emotions would be dealt with the same way.
The basic algorithm for dealing with anything,
is that large enough?
OK.
The basic algorithm for dealing with anything
is break it up into its pieces, learn
to keep track of the pieces in real time,
learn how not to interfere with the pieces,
focus on the individual pieces until you
experience each individual piece as effortless spirit,
and then focus on the aggregate as effortless spirit.
That's the basic algorithm for everything
within the mindfulness practice.
There's many other practices.
But the basic, if you want to have one,
what is the basic that you do?
You break it up into its components.
You learn to keep track of the components.
You learn to not interfere with the components.
And then things deal in.
Well, whatever the components may be.
In the broad case of anything that involves a sense of self,
an emotion is a particular case of self.
Anything that involves a sense of self,
the components in this case are talk, image, and feel.
But there are subcomponents.
For example, feel has qualities, locations.
Those are subcomponents.
But basically, if it deals with self,
it's talk, image, and feel.
Whether it's the sense of self as controller,
self as perceiver, self as sufferer,
it's going to be talk, image, and feel.
So we can go from the most general algorithm,
break it up into its components.
You learn to keep track of the components.
You learn how to not interfere with them.
That's called equanimity.
That process reaches a certain critical momentum.
And each of the components, when you pay attention
to them individually, dissolves back into spirit energy.
Then you collectively pay attention to them.
And the whole thing dissolves back into spirit energy.
And at that point, you have a spiritual solution
to the problem.
That's the general algorithm.
Specifically, if it's emotion, it's
going to be talk, image, and feel.
Yes?
My question, in my work, it seems
I have had a lot of people.
I do some body work.
And a lot of people are dealing with difficult emotions.
And even friends in my life, and this
is something for myself, too.
But the problem seems to lie with the people
I'm working with, with the equanimity, where
the emotion is there.
And I can, even in myself, with other people,
get them to feel it where it is in the body.
But it's the mind that comes in.
So it's not OK to just let go and feel it.
And that's just really strong, the judging mind.
So I guess I just wanted to hear a little bit about.
Typically, if that becomes a problem,
what I try, you've got to then try it.
It's a matter of trying things, seeing what works.
I'll try to have them watch the thoughts, the judging thoughts.
I find that that's, I mean, they can do that to a certain point.
But there's so much identification
with the thoughts.
So it's just a matter of practicing this problem.
Got to do more.
Yeah, I mean, you're not going to get an Arnold Schwarzenegger
body lifting weights every week.
It takes a certain amount of work
to develop an extraordinary strength.
And if they think that they're going
to be able to deal with the forces that fuck up
life and human history with just mindfulness light,
well, that's just unrealistic.
It takes industrial strength mindfulness.
Yes?
How do you know when you're ready to be a facilitator?
What we look for is that you're very familiar
with the techniques as we present them,
that you have used them successfully for dealing
with real life issues.
So you have the confidence.
And then, although it's in no way required,
it's a nice feature if you have had previous experience
in communication with people and that kind of stuff.
But that's not an absolute.
I mean, many of our facilitators have not
had previous experience.
But somebody that we know already
has communication skills, it's very nice if they've also had.
But the main criteria we look for
are, have you done enough retreats
that you're very familiar with the techniques?
Because you're going to have to guide people
through techniques.
And the other is, do you have the experiential confidence?
Because you've used it for real stuff.
Because you're going to have to guide people
through real stuff.
So that's how you know.
Through having done the practice of meditation,
I've become painfully aware at times of the fact
that there's a very active filtering mechanism in the mind,
which, in the short term, tends to prevent me from seeing
certain very obvious truths.
Because I tend to filter the world through my ego concept
and my identity of who I am.
And if it's inconsistent with that,
I tend to reject that information.
So extrapolation, I assume that this is true for other people
as well.
And I know from experience that just staying
in the meditation, putting your face up against the wall,
and facing those things that appear to be painful works.
And there's a process that tends to dissolve the filtering
mechanism.
In everyday interactions with people,
and also a person that teaches context,
it's very likely I do run into those kinds of situations.
It's very obvious that the person is not
looking at something, refuses to look at it.
There's nothing that one can, or it
doesn't appear to be that you can actually say anything,
because they're just going to reject you out of hand.
It's completely inconsistent.
And the normal reaction, I think, in daily life
is people start to get mad at each other,
get into an argument, and so on.
So I wonder if you could say something about it.
I think that's an active, I know there's a subtle teaching
aspect to it, but maybe there's something more to it.
Well, yeah, I think that's a really, really nicely
formulated description of the situation.
The way I conceive it for myself
is that my job is just to do the best I can.
And sometimes that may not be very good, but I can try again.
In the Catholic Church, they talk
about invincible ignorance.
That's their word for the phenomenon
that they have a nice term for that.
It's like, this person has structured the thing
so that it's invincible.
There's no chinks that you can get into it.
Of course, in their interpretation,
that was what they perceived as the reason why
certain people wouldn't convert to Catholicism,
no matter what, because they had invincible ignorance.
Anyway, be that as it may.
Maybe more specific than, obviously,
love and kindness is an important aspect
of that interaction.
But it can be a thing of, well, OK, so I'll just back off
and not say anything.
Or is there value in repeating?
Yeah.
Well, when you encounter invincible ignorance
in a person, it's just like there's no way to get in.
Strangely enough, I brought it up apropos of Christianity,
because this is the kind of thing
you're likely to encounter, invincible ignorance,
if you try to describe meditation
to a born-again Christian who's convinced that it's
the work of the devil.
OK.
That might be an example of it.
Just mentioned you run into it with Buddhists also.
If you want to see a lot of that,
just get in the Buddhist chat rooms on the net,
the World Wide Web.
I totally avoid that aspect of it.
It is the apotheosis of dharma ego.
I mean, it's just amazing what goes on
in those so-called Buddhist chat groups.
Not all of them, but some of them.
It's like you don't know whether to laugh or cry.
But anyway, yeah, it could be anything.
You try to justify Zen to the Nam-myoho-renge-kyo people.
I don't want to single out Protestant Christians,
but that is something that you might encounter
as a pretty good example of somebody
that's pretty armored, OK, as far as getting anything in.
Here's how I approach it.
First of all, when you can't communicate, it causes anger.
Well, have a complete experience of the anger
so it doesn't even need to show on the surface
unless it's appropriate, which very seldom is,
so that at least it doesn't degenerate to that level.
That alone is quite a deep training, I would say.
Because here, I'm so invested in communicating.
I mean, look at all the investment that I have.
Even if I don't have an investment in my ego as a teacher,
I certainly have a huge investment in communication.
And when that doesn't work, one is likely to experience anger.
So all I can say is, it's talk, image, and feel.
Therefore, it's effortless vibrating space.
And if you can train yourself to be able to experience it that way
on the fly as the communication process is deteriorating,
perhaps in a public venue, pretty good.
You're doing pretty good.
So that's one thing.
And that's a general principle.
We can always work on that.
The other thing is, I tend to...
It's like, OK, I lost this chess game,
meaning communication broke down.
So then I'll still try to make a game out of it.
I'll try to say, well, can I figure out
if the same moves happen next time?
What can I do different?
And a lot of times what happens is,
I don't really have a very good answer on that one.
And then maybe six months down the line,
a year down the line,
it'll suddenly come to me intuitively out of nowhere.
Oh, you know what?
This would really work for the next time
that the mid-game gets into this configuration, OK?
And it's like, OK, good.
And I'll just remember, and then I'll write it down.
That's when I make it real, get it more over.
Say, OK, I think this would be a good strategy
for that kind of situation.
I tend to look upon these things
not so much in terms of individual interactions,
but interactions come in types, OK?
And I'm working on types so that if I get better with,
like, OK, communicating Buddhist meditation
to a born-again Christian who is convinced
that you're the avatar of the devil.
I've actually had them come up to me in public and say,
you are the devil incarnate.
And they really believe it.
They really believe it.
So for me, like, if I could ever communicate
with somebody that was in that state,
that would be an incredible coup.
Now, maybe it'll take me 40 years to figure out something.
And maybe the something that I figure out
may not be all that great, but it
gets in one of the chinks someplace
for that class of communication problems.
Then, well, that's pretty cool, OK?
And I take joy in that.
So that's sort of my take on that.
Along these lines, the experience that I have the most
is not you are the devil incarnate,
but it is a very tiresome, tedious, intellectual bullshit
that is launched on the subject of meditation
that I feel oftentimes I get sucked into.
OK, I understand.
If we take out the bullshit piece, what we're left with,
we're left with an elaborate intellectual defense mechanism.
You don't have to deal with it.
OK, that's the first thing to remember.
You don't have to disabuse everybody
of their ignorance in the universe.
Maybe that's just too tiresome and too tedious to deal with.
So OK, so you don't deal with that.
You just deal with other situations.
On the other hand, if it were me, but this is just me,
I'd get really excited and interested in figuring out
an optimal response to each one of those intellectual points.
Now that's a tedious, huge task, but it
could be extremely instructive.
For me, I think I'd find it very instructive.
And I would take 100% responsibility
for the communication.
In other words, if I got into this as a project,
and I might spend years on it with a certain person that
was that way, I'd spend years on it.
It would be like a series of chess games,
but not against the person, against
their invincible ignorance or the non-communication.
And each time I lost the game, I'd go back,
and I'd analyze and see what could I do and whatever.
And I think I'd learn a lot.
I think I'd learn a lot.
But I'm not saying you have to do this.
It's very tedious.
That's true.
But like I say, what I hold out for myself
is that perfection in conceptual teaching
would come when, basically, you can get through to anybody.
It's 100% your responsibility, 0% theirs.
You've so worked through things that you might not
get all the way through, but at least you get an aha
of some sort.
And that's very fulfilling.
Couldn't you just respect your differences?
That's why I said you don't have to deal with it, necessarily.
I think your way of putting it was better than mine,
when I said you don't have to do it.
But really, at the deeper level, you
can just respect the differences.
Just let that person be that way.
Well, in that situation, it's virtually
equivalent to speaking to a person who
speaks a different language.
So there's not so much to get upset,
but knowing that there is no communication.
But you can also take it on as a challenge.
But you make it a fun challenge.
Yeah, the excitement.
I loved your word, excitement, there.
Take it on as this.
I was having a grand baby with a very aggressive thing
about meditation.
And so I simply said, tell me why you hate it.
You know, this enthusiastic voice.
And they went on for about five minutes,
and they couldn't figure out any more reasons they hated it.
And then we got on to a different level.
But it was exciting.
It was kind of fun.
Tell me every reason you hate it.
By the way, there is historical precedent
for what you're just describing.
It's called the Socratic method.
This is how Socrates worked.
When he encountered objection, he
would encourage them to keep objecting and give them
all the time they wanted.
And then it would all sort of come out.
But the Socratic method is a two-edged sword.
Because behind Socrates were the sophists.
And they used that method as a trick.
It's just like lawyers tell you, don't give any more testimony
than you're asked.
Because everything that you give could be used.
So the sophists knew this.
So what they would do is, it was a very clever trick.
Because you give a person a chance
to completely vent their spleen and really express themselves.
Everybody wants to do that, right?
And you're listening, and you're attentive, or whatever.
But what the sophists would do is, of course,
the more information that was coming out,
the more clever things that they were figuring out
how to use that information.
So there's a two-edged sword on the Socratic method.
A teacher should not use the edge that is the trick.
You should allow them to express themselves,
and then start sincerely responding to what comes up.
But when you mentioned about the armor,
what was the Catholic term you said?
Invincible ignorance.
So sometimes in my experience, when
I'm in conversation with someone or an argument,
they find the hole to get to me.
And that's when judgment within myself
arises as to whether I'm as right on as I think I am.
Not about a particular point, but the practice.
And I haven't heard you use the J-word, judgment.
And I was wondering if you had something
to say about self-judgment.
Once again, I'll answer with a question.
This is with regard to what sorts of, you said,
with regard to the practice.
Well, I guess because that's what we're talking about today.
But in my life, it can happen in financial matters.
OK, so broadly.
In other words, you, yes, I think
I understand the question.
This is another technique, by the way.
If I think I understand, but I'm not sure,
I'll repeat the question back and see
if they agree that, yes, this is what, in fact, I'm asking.
You're arguing with somebody about something.
And they seem to win a point.
And then you leave the argument.
And you have some doubts about, well, maybe they're right
and I'm wrong.
Is that correct?
Well, of course, that's a legitimate thing
